{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3558271,"name":"jacqueline","username":"jr190","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/919ad9/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T14:05:39.378Z","cooked":"

this is my first year coaching a team, its their rookie year. right now I am working on ordering some gearboxes for the alage manipulator. specifically an arm that is about 16 inches long of 1*2 aluminum tube 2 of those parallel with a hextube connecting them with a neo 550 at the end. I was planning on using a neo to change the angle of the arm since we have a couple on hand and know the cheapest option is probably a max planetary gearbox but I have no idea how to even start picking a gear ratio for that.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T14:05:39.378Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":52,"reads":144,"readers_count":143,"score":303.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495775,"topic_slug":"gear-ratio-question","display_username":"jacqueline","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35005,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/gear-ratio-question/495775/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558303,"name":"Brooke Flynn","username":"BrookeF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brookef/{size}/251883_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T14:40:08.256Z","cooked":"

Personally if I had the funds, I would go and buy one or two of each stage (3:1, 4:1, etc.) and test from there.

(I know that there are some fancy maths you could do but I wouldn‚Äôt know where to begin with that though)

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T14:45:15.803Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":136,"readers_count":135,"score":37.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495775,"topic_slug":"gear-ratio-question","display_username":"Brooke Flynn","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71936,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"- She/Her"},"post_url":"/t/gear-ratio-question/495775/2","reactions":[{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558318,"name":"Ian McTavish","username":"Ian_McTavish","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/b5a626/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T14:58:43.123Z","cooked":"

For an arm you have two key aspects - mass of the arm and length. You‚Äôve specified the length (i.e. 16 inches). For the mass either model it in CAD or simply take the components and weigh them. You can also look on vendor websites to find the mass of different components.

ReCalc is a popular calculator to determine gear ratios. Here is an example gear calculation for an arm using your specs. The graph allows you to determine if your gear ratio will work. In my example a 100:1 reduction will move the arm. Looking at Rev‚Äôs maxplanetary gearboxes this can be achieved with a 5:1, 5:1 and 4:1 stage. (Rev robotics specs)

Some notes: watch the current limits. Just because you have a 40 amp breaker does not mean you want to run at 40 amps the entire time!
Always give yourself some wiggle room. If your gear combination is just pushing the limit what happens when another robot pushes down on your arm?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T14:58:43.123Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":112,"readers_count":111,"score":72.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495775,"topic_slug":"gear-ratio-question","display_username":"Ian McTavish","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.reca.lc/arm?armMass=%7B%22s%22%3A15%2C%22u%22%3A%22lbs%22%7D&comLength=%7B%22s%22%3A16%2C%22u%22%3A%22in%22%7D¤tLimit=%7B%22s%22%3A30%2C%22u%22%3A%22A%22%7D&efficiency=100&endAngle=%7B%22s%22%3A90%2C%22u%22%3A%22deg%22%7D&iterationLimit=10000&motor=%7B%22quantity%22%3A1%2C%22name%22%3A%22NEO%22%7D&ratio=%7B%22magnitude%22%3A100%2C%22ratioType%22%3A%22Reduction%22%7D&startAngle=%7B%22s%22%3A0%2C%22u%22%3A%22deg%22%7D","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ReCalc","clicks":6},{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/maxplanetary-system-kit/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"MAXPlanetary System Kit - REV Robotics","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17356,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/gear-ratio-question/495775/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558325,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T15:20:08.713Z","cooked":"

In addition to powering your pivot appropriately (the post above gives you great advice on that), the design of your arm pivot is equally important. If you aren‚Äôt sure about good pivot designs, frcdesign.org is a great place to learn. Large-diameter splined tubing from Rev or WCP can be the basis of a solid and easy-to-create pivot.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T15:20:08.713Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":88,"readers_count":87,"score":32.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495775,"topic_slug":"gear-ratio-question","display_username":"paulonis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.frcdesign.org/mechanism-examples/pivots/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Pivot Examples | FRCDesign.org","clicks":2},{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/rev-21-2520/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"MAXSpline Shaft - 47in - REV Robotics","clicks":0},{"url":"https://wcproducts.com/products/splinexl","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"SplineXL ‚Äì WestCoast Products","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/gear-ratio-question/495775/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558326,"name":"John Hascall (he)","username":"john3928","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T15:20:31.924Z","cooked":"
Ian_McTavish:

In my example a 100:1 reduction will move the arm. Looking at Rev‚Äôs maxplanetary gearboxes this can be achieved with a 5:1, 5:1 and 4:1 stage.

In our robot, I think we have a single 5:1 stage and our final ‚Äústage‚Äù is the chain drive.

IMG_2510898√ó910 221 KB

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T15:20:31.924Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":23.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495775,"topic_slug":"gear-ratio-question","display_username":"John Hascall (he)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46267,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Opinions expressed are mine only"},"post_url":"/t/gear-ratio-question/495775/5","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558337,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T15:31:31.492Z","cooked":"
Ian_McTavish:

You‚Äôve specified the length (i.e. 16 inches)

Its probably worth mentioning that, for the purposes of this calculation, the length should really be to the center of mass for the arm rather than the overall length. In practical terms, it very well may not make much of a difference depending on the specific arm design.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T15:31:31.492Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":76,"readers_count":75,"score":25.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495775,"topic_slug":"gear-ratio-question","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/gear-ratio-question/495775/6","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558370,"name":"Ian McTavish","username":"Ian_McTavish","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/b5a626/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T16:04:12.257Z","cooked":"

If you have a chain and sprocket (or belt and pulley) that gear ratio has to be included in the calculations. Our team typically uses a MaxPlanetary for the first stage or two and then either chain and sprocket or belt and pulley depending on our design choices.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T16:04:12.257Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":61,"readers_count":60,"score":27.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495775,"topic_slug":"gear-ratio-question","display_username":"Ian McTavish","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":46267,"username":"john3928","name":"John Hascall (he)","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17356,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/gear-ratio-question/495775/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558371,"name":"Ian McTavish","username":"Ian_McTavish","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/b5a626/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T16:05:46.405Z","cooked":"

Absolutely, we tend to use the overall length because it is quick and easy to make calculations that should be safe enough before we are done the CAD process. Having a variety of gear ratio options gives us lots of flexibility.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T16:05:46.405Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":61,"readers_count":60,"score":27.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495775,"topic_slug":"gear-ratio-question","display_username":"Ian McTavish","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":9105,"username":"Fletch1373","name":"Fletch","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17356,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/gear-ratio-question/495775/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558408,"name":"Brandon Liatys","username":"Brandon_L","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brandon_l/{size}/225700_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T16:53:56.387Z","cooked":"

While technically correct, I always end up assuming the center of mass is near the end of the arm (depending on what the mechanism looks like)

If you do your gear math to assume worst case, it will still work in the real life better caae

Basically if I have a arm with a manipulator on the end, the arm material itself is say 2lbs, the manipulator is 10lbs, and the arm is for example 24" long, I‚Äôll just say it‚Äôs 12lbs on the end of a 24" long arm. No need to really figure out where exactly the center of mass is.

Thank you all, I am thinking doing a 9:1 gear box with some belts giving another 9:1 or maybe a little higher on the belts I will have to see what they have in stock might be enough to try the hard part is just going to be fitting it all in the small space
